docs.text: Preferences This is where you can find a few settings, which will change the way you work with the addon. Changelog This is where the most important parts of the changelog for the newest version are located. UI Reverse Layer Order This option will reverse the order the layers are displayed in and also reverse the move up and down buttons, to match the layer order. Move Over Closed Group When you move a layer towards a closed group and this option is enabled, instead of moving in the group, it will treat the whole group as a single layer and move past it. Keymaps HDRI Rotation Shortcut This option will disable the ability to rotate the background image in the viewport with your mouse. Here you can also set the shortcut that will start the modal. Custom Groups The folder path you specify here should lead to a folder, which has your custom assets. These will get imported when you activate the addon in a file. You can also import them with an operator . Blend Files These should have your custom node groups in them. The name of the files themselves does not matter, it's just the names of the node groups in your files which will matter. Thumbnails If you have a folder called thumbnails in your specified folder, the thumbnails located in that folder will be imported into your files. These should match the names of the node groups in your .blend files. You can find more information on this here .

docs.text: Usage Layer Painter is integrated into an active tool, which can be accessed in Object and Texture Painting mode. This means, that if you want to use the addon, you need to have the active tool selected . To get started do the following: Select the active tool Open the N-Panel under the Layer Painter or Tool tab or open the topbar Press the Activate Layer Painter button This will open the Layer Painter workspace which you need to use the addon. If you close or remove the workspace you can use this button to switch to or add the workspace back.
docs.title: Active tool

docs.text: Usage Both the layer stack and the layer settings live in this panel. The advantage is, that you can close it at all times, just by pressing N . Shortcuts You can also use shortcuts to open these panels, which allows you to have the N-Panel closed at all times. These shortcuts are: Layer Stack: CTRL + RIGHTMOUSE Layer Settings: RIGHTMOUSE Toggle painting This button is only a temporary solution. It can be used to exit out of texture painting mode when Layer Painter automatically switches to it. It also prevents the automatic toggling of texture painting mode. Once this bug is resolved, this will be removed. A Layer Painter active tool will be added to texture painting mode, which can then show the Layer Painter settings. Layer Stack The layer stack has the dropdowns for material and channel selection as well as the layer operators. It also has all the layers of your materials. Material Dropdown This dropdown allows you to select the material you're currently editing. Tip If there are any issues with your layer stack, try reselecting the active material. This will reload the layers and might fix issues. Reset Material This button will show up if the addon wasn't able to recognize the node layout of your material. This shouldn't appear when you don't edit the material by hand, except for once when you haven't done anything with the material. The button will remove all nodes in the selected material and set up the nodes required for the addon. Channel Dropdown This is the channel you are currently editing. "Layer" will affect the entire layer, while the other channels will just change the current channel. This dropdown will have an affect on the following things: Layer Stack: All channels can have different opacities and channels can be hidden invdividually. The individual channels also have a blending mode, "Layer" doesn't have that. Masks: If you add a mask, it will be added for the selected channel. This means that you can have different masks for different channels. Channel Preview This adds an emmission node inbetween the active channel and the output node. It's a way to preview the raw color of the channel. This setting won't work if "Layer" is selected. Layer operators These operators all depend on which layer is selected! The operators function in order of appearance: Add fill layer : This will add a fill layer above the selected layer Add paint layer : This will add a paint layer above the selected layer Add node group layer : This will add a node group layer above the selected layer Add group layer : This will add a group above the selected layer Move layer up: This will move the selected layer up in the layer stack Move layer down: This will move the selected layer down in the layer stack Delete layer: This will delete the selected layer When you have no layers in your material, there will be a button to copy an existing material. This will add the layers from the material selected in the poup to your active material. Layers A single layer looks like this. The elements in order of appearance: Visibility : This changes the visibility of the selected channel Layer selection : This will select this layer and display the layers settings in the settings panel Mask selection : This will select this layer and display the mask settings in the settings panel Layer name : This changes the name of this layer. There are a few names which are not allowed. If you enter one of them, the layers name will be changed to "Unnamed" Blending mode : This setting does not exist for "Layer". If another channel is selected, this will change the blending mode of this channel Opacity : This changes the opacity of the selected channel or the layer. You can enter a value or drag your mouse Layer tag : This is a color tag for the layer which makes it easier to identifie in the layer panel and in the node editor. The random color setting can be turned off Groups A group layer looks like this. The elements in order of appearance: Selection : This selects this group Expand : This expands the group and shows the layers inside it Name : The name of the group Visibility : This sets the visibility of the group and the layers inside it Layer settings If you have a layer selected, the settings for this layer will be shown here. If you have a layers mask selected, the settings for that mask will be shown here. The layer settings are specific for the type of the selected layer. Fill Layer Paint Layer Node Group Layer You can see what the mask settings look like here .

docs.text: Custom Node Groups Custom Node Groups give you a lot of possibilities to create complex materials quickly. You can also create masks with procedural textures. You can use the provided file, to help you create your node groups. This file has premade node groups , like a color ramp. This is useful, because color ramp values can't normally be edited outside the group. Using Custom Groups When you have a file with custom node groups, you can add them to the folder that you selected in the addon preferences . There can be multiple files in this folder. The names of the files does not matter. The groups will be imported when activating the addon in the toolbar or when using the import button .
docs.title: Basics

docs.text: Custom Node Layers Custom node groups for layers can be used in Node Group Layers . When creating a node group for a layer make sure the name starts with two "_". The node groups name should look like this: __Name of the node group Outputs The outputs should represent the channel names . You don't need to have all channels. Unused channels will be hidden automatically. The outputs names can be as follows: Color / Base Color , Metalness / Metallic , Roughness , Height , Normal Normal channel The normal channel does not need the output of a normal map node, but the raw color. Inputs Normal inputs will be represented as they are in the node group. There are a few special input types. These will be drawn differently in the layer settings panel. The addon detects these channels based on their name. These are the special names: BEVEL_MASK : This input will try to get a bevel mask when the node group is selected or when a bevel mask is baked AO_MASK : This input will try to get a ambient occlusion mask when the node group is selected or when a AO mask is baked IMAGE_ label of the input : This will allow you to select an image SEPARATOR : This will add a separator in the layer settings UI, to create some room between settings LABEL_ label of the input : This will create an expandable panel in the layer settings UI. When the default value of this input is set to 1, the panel will be expanded by default This is how a node group will look in the UI with some of the special inputs in use:
docs.title: Custom Node Layers

docs.text: Generating the thumbnails You don't have to use the provided file to generate your thumbnails, but they will look better integrated if you do. Just make sure that you use a square image; a resolution of 300x300px should be enough. The thumbnails for the custom node groups can be created with the provided .blend file. Simply append your custom node group to that file. Depending on if you want to create a mask or a layer node group, apply the corresponding material to the Suzanne object in the scene. Then connect the sockets in the node editor and render the image. Using custom thumbnails The thumbnails should be in a folder called "thumbnails". This folder needs to be located in the same folder you chose in the preferences . Then make sure the name of the thumbnail images filename fits the name of your custom node group. If the group is called "Custom Mask__", the image should be called "Custom Mask__.png". The thumbnails will be imported together with the node groups, when the addon is activated. You can also use the buttons in the topbar , to import them. If no thumbnail is provided, a default image will be used. This is the silhouette of the Suzanne model.

docs.text: Blendermarket | Gumroad | Blenderartists | Twitter Introducing Layer Painter Layer Painter is an addon for Blender 2.8, that makes use of Eevee and especially the Look-Dev viewport, to give real-time feedback when creating materials. It adds a layer system , which is a similar approach to a lot of 2D software. Help This documentation page should cover most of you problems, so be sure to see if you can find a solution here first. If you can't find a solution here, contact me on one of the following platforms: If you bought the addon on Blendermarket you can go here You can also contact me on Twitter On Blenderartists there are also other people that can help you Discussion The most discussion happens on Blenderartists . Here you can ask me about features and suggest improvements. This is also where I share the status of updates and new features. General Notes It's important to know, that you should not edit the node tree . Layer Painter needs a specific node setup to store the layers. Things like if nodes are expaned will have and effect on your layers and might brake them if changed manually.
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Provided files Use the newest Blender version When you install Layer Painter, please make sure that you're using blender 2.80 which you can get here . When you download the addon you will get a .zip file. You will need to unpack that file and will get two files: layerpainter_v1.1.zip This is the actual addon which you will have to install custom_assets.zip These are just some files that will help you create custom node groups . You don't need them for the installation. Installing the addon Remove previous versions! If you have a previous version of Layer Painter installed, make sure to remove that version and then restart blender before installing the new version. The addon is installed like every other addon in blender. Go to the Add-ons tab in the Blender preferences and press Install . Select the layerpainter_v1.1.zip and select Install Add-on from file . Then click the checkbox and restart Blender . Custom assets The custom_assets.zip includes a few files, that will come in handy for creating custom node groups . These files are not required in any way, they're just there to help you create your own assets.
docs.title: Installation

docs.text: Known Issues Issue The PBR textures folder property won't open the filebrowser. This is a known bug which is not yet resolved. Issue The material turns pink. This is not directly an issue with the addon. It's more a limit of Blender and your graphics card. If you have to many textures/ nodes in your material, Blender just can't handle it anymore. I hope that this improves over time. If you want to know more about this, you can go here . Solution There is no real solution for this, as it's just something that need to improve with Blender, but you can do a few things to counter this: Bake your material to a single layer (will obviously remove the issue, but also your layers) Clear your file of unused textures
docs.title: Known Issues

docs.text: What does "supported addons" mean? At the moment there are two addons that are "supported" by Layer Painter. This means that if you have them installed, some of their features are integrated into the Layer Painter workflow in some form. This does not mean that the code of these addons is in Layer Painter. If you don't have them installed and don't want to, you can disable their information buttons in the settings . Lily Surface Scrapper This addon by Élie Michel allows you to import textures from a URL . This means you can for example go to texturehaven.com and select a textureset. Then copy the URL and enter it in the addons popup. The addon is supported like this: When you're editing a Fill Layer , you can press the URL button and enter the URL. Layer Painter will then import the downloaded textures and try to apply them to the correct channel . This will speed up your workflow a lot, because you don't have to download and select your textures manually, but can just enter the URL and the rest will happen for you. You can get the addon here . Data Manager Disclaimer This addon is not yet released. As soon as it is, these features will be available. This addon by Grant Wilk allows you to clean and organize your blend files. You can get statistics about the objects, images, materials and much more in your file. The addon is supported like this: There is a small white indicator in the Layer settings panel , which will show you if there are any unused images in your file. When the indicator turns red , you can click it, which will open a popup where you can remove the unused textures. This will keep your files a lot cleaner when working with a lot of textures. You can get the addon here .

docs.text: Layer Basics A layer is a representation of a particular order of nodes in your material. This means that Layer Painter will generate nodes while you only work with the Layer UI. Because Layer Painter needs to find the layers and nodes in your material, you shouldn't edit nodes by hand if you want to keep the layer view. A layer has PBR channels , which are Base Color, Metalness, Roughness, Height and Normal . Additionally, you can enable Emission and Alpha . These channels can be influenced by constant values, textures or node groups depending on the layer type . There are three different layer types, which all have different funcions and usecases: Fill Layer Paint Layer Node Group Layer Layer Settings The settings of the selected layer can be found in the Layer Settings Panel. The first few settings are the same for every type of layer, the rest is different: Name of the layer and the layer type Visibility toggles for each channel First Layer When you add the first layer, you'll be asked if you want to enable the optional emission and alpha channels. These can then be used in all future layers.

docs.text: What does it do? A Fill Layer can have a constant value or a texture for each channel. There are different ways of selecting the texture. The constant value is a number for Metalness, Roughness and Height and a color for Base Color and Normal. What is it for? A Fill Layer can be used if you just want to change the basic look of your material or if you want to work with textures. Settings After the general layer settings you can see the following buttons: Files : This button will open the file browser. Here you can select a single texture in a folder with a PBR textureset. The addon will try to import as many of the channel textures as possible, based on their name. It uses the tags that can be specified in the preferences of the Node Wrangler addon Assets : This button will open a popup with a thumbnail selection. Here you will see the Base Color texture of the PBR set. The filepath for these textures can be specified in the settings panel . When you select a texture, the importing works the same as with the Files button URL : This will use the Lily Surface Scrapper addon to import a textureset from a URL Then there are the settings for the visible channels. To the right of every channel is a texture and a folder icon , which will add a texture node or open the filebrowser and allow you to imort a single texture for that channel. Roughness / Glossiness When importing glossiness textures, they will get added to the roughness channel. There is a toggle next to the texture selection, which will invert the corresponding texture. This is automatically activated when a glossiness texture is loaded.

docs.text: General Behavior You can add layers to groups by moving them. The layer will get moved into the group when it's directly below or above and is moved in the corresponding direction. When a layer is in a group it will be affected by the groups mask and visibility. If the visibility of the group is disabled, the layers in the group won't be visible. The mask of the group will be overlayed on the masks of the layer itself. Groups can't be nested. The button to add a group will be disabled when a layer inside a group is selected or when no layer is in the material. Moving When a group is moved, every layer in the group will be moved as well. When you move a layer out of a group, it won't be affected by the groups settings anymore. Masks You can change the mask of the group when you have it selected. It's independent of the channel, but other than that it works the same as the layer masks.
docs.title: Group Layer

docs.text: What does it do? A Node Group Layer uses the outputs of a node group to affect the channels. This means that you can have complex node setups to use in a layer of your material. You can then tweak the inputs of this node group to change the look of your material. These groups can also use the baked AO and Bevel maps to affect only parts of the mesh. What is it for? These layers can be used if you want to create a base for a material or get a quick result. If you want to, this also allows you to work with nodes , to create your own groups . Settings After the general layer settings you might see the message , that unused channels have been hidden. This will appear if the node group does not have an output for every channel. Then there is a dropdown and a thumbnail selection for selecting a group. Below that, there are the settings for every input of the node group. Some inputs do special things, like creating collapsable panels or texture inputs. You can find more information about that here . If you see a text like this, you now that the node group uses an AO or Bevel mask to change the look of the material. You can see how to bake them here . The textures will be selected automatically when their baked.

docs.text: What does it do? A paint layer allows you to paint textures in all the different channels. These textures are transparent by default. When a paint layer is selected in one of the paintable channels (all except the layer channel), Layer Painter will automatically switch to texture painting mode. It will switch out of that mode when a different layer or mask is selected. What is it for? You can use a Paint Layer if you want to paint your own textures or want to put stencils on your object. Be aware that Paint Layers will take up the most resources of all layer types. Settings Paint Layers only have the general layer settings, as the rest is done with the painted textures.

docs.text: Masks Basics Masks are black and white values, that show where the layer is visible and where it isn't. These values can be defined by textures or node groups . By default the mask is set to None, which means that the layer is completely visible. Masks are per channel . This means, that every channel can have its own mask or you can set a mask for the entire channel. You can choose what channel your editing with the channel dropdown . Mask Settings The settings of the selected channels mask can be found in the Layer Settings Panel . The first few settings are the same for every type of mask, the rest is different: Name of the layer and the selected channel Dropdown and thumbnail selection for the mask type Mask bake button There are texture masks and node group masks , which have different settings.
docs.title: Basics

docs.text: What does it do? A Node Group Mask uses the output of a node group to affect the layers visibility. This means that you can have complex node setups to create a mask for your layer. You can then tweak the inputs of this node group to change the mask. These groups can also use the baked AO and Bevel maps to affect only parts of the mesh. What is it for? These masks can be used if you want to create quick but complex masks. This also allows you to take advantage of AO and bevel mask textures. If you want to, this also allows you to work with nodes , to create your own groups . Settings Below that, there are the settings for every input of the node group. Some inputs do special things, like creating collapsable panels or texture inputs. You can find more information about that here . If you see a text like this, you now that the node group uses an AO or Bevel mask to change the look of the material. You can see how to bake them here . The textures will be selected automatically when their baked. Bake Masks Node Group masks can be baked to images with the bake button. This will ask you for a resolution and will then bake the mask to a texture which can then be edited. This can be good to save resources. Obviously it also means that you can't tweak the settings anymore.

docs.text: Topbar Basics The topbar holds both, settings and tools . You can bake masks and the layers to PBR textures, as well as change settings for the workspace and the material. Special buttons The first button can be used to toggle the texture editor. This will open a 2D view, which you can use to view your textures. The second button will hide all unused objects, meaning all that do not have the selected material.
